channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
item.media:description: Fidel Castro after arriving in Havana on Jan. 8, 1959. Mr. Castro’s revolution was welcomed by Cubans like Juan Montes Torre, a poor laborer at the time. “It was an emotional shock,” Mr. Montes recalled. “These bearded men, poorly dressed — they won! And on behalf of the lower classes!”
item.description: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Donald Trump’s Threat to Close Door Reopens Old Wounds in Cuba
item.media:description: President Obama met with the Cuban president, Raúl Castro, in Havana in March.
item.description: In a post on Twitter, he said he would “terminate” the pact President Obama made if Cuba is unwilling to make “a better deal for the Cuban people.”
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE, AZAM AHMED and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Subdued Cuba Prepares Memorial for Castro
item.description: A two-day memorial and a period of “Duelo Nacional,” or national mourning, will offer Cubans a chance to pay their respects to the longtime leader.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Little Fidel in All of Us
item.media:description: People in Miami reacting to the news of the death of Fidel Castro.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: Who would any of us be if he hadn’t rearranged our destinies and caused this rupture in our lives?
item.dc:creator: ACHY OBEJAS

item.title: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
item.media:description: Fidel Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a revolutionary hero by others.
item.description: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY DePALMA

item.title: Another Mass Grave Dug by ISIS in Iraq, and a Ghastly Ritual Renewed
item.media:description: A tied and decomposed body at a mass grave found at a trash dump on the outskirts of Hamam al-Alil, Iraq.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The Islamic State has been resorting to a horrific practice that dates back to Saddam Hussein and his regime’s industrial-scale killings.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Alexandria Journal: Remembering My Mother’s Alexandria
item.media:description: The wedding of my maternal grandparents in Alexandria, Egypt, in the 1940s.
item.description: Our correspondent returned to the Egyptian city this fall to find a place as full of despair as her mother’s of the 1960s was full of hope and anticipation.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: A.N.C. Rejects Calls for Jacob Zuma to Quit South African Presidency
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa in Johannesburg this month.
item.description: Leaders of the African National Congress, after a debate among party members, reaffirmed their support for the unpopular leader.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Norcia Journal: Italian Monastery Seeks Salvation in Beer After Devastating Quake
item.media:description: Father Nivakoff, who is from Connecticut, in the historical center of Norcia. The beer brewery that he and other monks operate was mostly spared.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Their basilica in ruins, monks from America believe their small brewing operation can help an entire town to recover from Italy’s worst earthquake since 1980.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Austria’s Far Right Sees a Prize Within Reach: The Presidency
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer, 45, above, is running neck and neck with Alexander Van der Bellen, 72, for Austria’s presidency. The vote will be on Sunday.
item.description: Immigration concerns and the election of Donald J. Trump in the United States are seen as giving Norbert Hofer an even chance to win the largely ceremonial role in voting on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Park Geun-hye, Embattled South Korean President, Says She’s Willing to Resign
item.description: Opposition lawmakers rejected the offer, calling it a ploy, and said they would call for a vote on Friday to impeach Ms. Park, who is embroiled in a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.N. Stiffens Sanctions on North Korea, Trying to Slow Its Nuclear March
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, in an undated photograph issued by his government’s Korean Central News Agency on Nov. 11.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The key to enforcing the Security Council’s new penalties on coal exports remains in the hands of China, North Korea’s principal coal customer.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: C.I.A. Chief Warns Donald Trump Against Tearing Up Iran Nuclear Deal
item.media:description: The C.I.A. director, John Brennan, in Washington in June. In an interview with the BBC, Mr. Brennan warned that the incoming administration needed to be skeptical about Russian promises.
item.description: John Brennan told the BBC that canceling the accord would be “the height of folly” and could lead to a nuclear arms race in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: A History of Air Disasters Involving Sports Teams
item.media:description: Rescue workers removing bodies of victims at the site of a plane crash on the outskirts of Medellín, Colombia, on Tuesday.
item.description: The crash of a plane carrying the Brazilian soccer club Chapecoense to a game in Colombia is one of several similar accidents stretching back decades.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: What in the World: On an Island Named for Ice, the Poets Are Just Getting Warmed Up
item.media:description: Poetician (2016), by Birgitta Jónsdóttir | DOWNLOAD
item.media:credit: Design and Illustration by Helga Dögg
item.description: In Iceland, people of all ages and every walk of life compose and publish verse. Cold, damp weather and long winter nights may be among the reasons.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Britain’s New £5 Note, Stronger and Safer, Isn’t Suitable for Vegetarians
item.media:description: To the dismay of vegans and vegetarians across Britain, the Bank of England has confirmed that tallow was used in the base of the new 5-pound notes.
item.description: The Bank of England has confirmed that tallow, a hard, fatty substance usually made from rendered beef or mutton suet, was used in the base of the new bills.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: 3 Chinese Rights Activists Disappear in Apparent State Crackdown
item.media:description: Jiang Tianyong in 2012.
item.description: The three men vanished within days of each other in different provinces, rights groups said, and only one has been charged by the police.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Indian Cinemas Must Play the National Anthem, Supreme Court Rules
item.media:description: A movie theater in Mumbai, India. Decades ago, Indian movie theaters routinely played the national anthem at the end of a movie, but the practice was discontinued.
item.description: The anthem, before every screening, is to be accompanied by images of the Indian flag, and the audience must stand, the ruling mandates.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Let Women Drive, a Saudi Prince Urges
item.media:description: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in 2015. In a four-page letter posted on his personal website, the prince argued that “it is high time that Saudi women started driving their cars.”
item.description: “Beyond being a rights issue, it is also an economic, developmental and social one,” Alwaleed bin Talal wrote in a four-page letter posted on his personal website.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Bid to Impeach South Korean Leader Stalls as Lawmakers Debate Her Offer to Quit
item.media:description: An effigy of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at a protest in Seoul, the capital, on Wednesday.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s offer to step down, without specifying a date, swayed some lawmakers, who said they were willing to accept an April departure.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Interpreter: French Election Hints at a European Shift Toward Russia
item.media:description: The winner of France’s center-right presidential primary, François Fillon, in October. Mr. Fillon has called for lifting sanctions on Russia and for partnering with Moscow to curtail immigration and terrorism.
item.description: François Fillon’s victory in a presidential primary suggests that a shift from confrontation to accommodation of Moscow has already begun in the region.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Twelve Detained After Turkish Dormitory Fire Kills Schoolgirls
item.description: The police in southern Turkey detained 12 people on Wednesday and sought two others over a fire that killed 11 schoolgirls and one other person.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Justin Trudeau Approves Oil Pipeline Expansion in Canada
item.media:description: A march in Vancouver, British Columbia, this month against the proposed expansion of the Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain project. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau approved the plan on Tuesday.
item.description: The Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain project would link the oil sands in Alberta to a tanker port in British Columbia, where there have been several protests against the plan.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: ‘Unintentional’ Human Error Led to Airstrikes on Syrian Troops, Pentagon Says
item.description: According to an official inquiry, the American-led attacks in September were conducted under the “good-faith belief” that the targets were Islamic State militants.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Obama to Send Aide to Fidel Castro’s Funeral
item.media:description: Benjamin J. Rhodes, center, a deputy national security adviser to President Obama, in Buenos Aires in March. He will attend the funeral for Fidel Castro in Cuba.
item.description: Benjamin J. Rhodes, a deputy national security adviser, will join the top American diplomat in Cuba at the funeral, an official said, citing the countries’ “complicated” relationship.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: What Is U.K.’s ‘Brexit’ Plan? Glimpse of a Notepad Stirs Up Intrigue
item.media:description: From left: David Davies, secretary of state for exiting the European Union; Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson; and Prime Minister Theresa May at a cabinet meeting in London this week.
item.description: A surreptitiously photographed page of notes reading “What’s the model? Have cake & eat” has fueled speculation about the official policy for leaving the European Union.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Thousands Flee Parts of Aleppo, Syria, as Assad’s Forces Gain Ground
item.media:description: Syrian families waited to board buses for government-controlled western Aleppo on Tuesday.
item.description: Leaflets dropped over the besieged city warned inhabitants, “If you don’t leave these areas quickly you will be annihilated.”
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: China Tightens Controls on Overseas Use of Its Currency
item.media:description: The headquarters of the People’s Bank of China, the central bank, in Beijing. The decision to restrict overseas use of the renminbi is a setback in China’s long-term drive to turn the currency into a rival to the dollar and the euro for international finance.
item.description: With money surging out of China, the Chinese central bank makes it harder for Chinese customers of banks to complete overseas transfers.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Emma Morano, World’s Oldest Person, Turns 117
item.media:description: Emma Morano blowing out candles on her 117th birthday on Tuesday in Pallanza, northern Italy.
item.description: She celebrated the occasion in her home in Italy, with some of the festivities shown live on the state broadcaster.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas, Re-elected as Fatah Leader, Moves to Solidify Power
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, third from right, the Palestinian Authority president, at a Fatah party conference on Tuesday in Ramallah, West Bank.
item.description: Under pressure from critics at home and abroad, Mr. Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, orchestrated his re-election as his party’s leader.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: Giant Arch, a Feat of Engineering, Now Covers Chernobyl Site in Ukraine
item.media:description: An arched shelter was slid into place over the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site in Ukraine on Tuesday. It is about 500 feet long, has a span of 800 feet and is 350 feet high.
item.description: The shelter, under construction since 2010, covers the deteriorating steel and concrete sarcophagus hastily built after the nuclear accident 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Hong Kong Appears Ready to Bar a Third Lawmaker Over Oath
item.media:description: The legislator Lau Siu-lai addressed protesters outside the High Court in Hong Kong this month.
item.description: The move signaled a possible escalation of a campaign against a separatist movement, even though the legislator had not called for independence.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Militants Attack Indian Army Base in Nagrota, Inflaming Tensions With Pakistan
item.media:description: Indian soldiers on Tuesday outside a camp in Nagrota, the army’s regional headquarters in the state of Jammu and Kashmir.
item.description: Assailants disguised as police officers took hostages and killed seven Indian soldiers before being shot and killed.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Taking a Selfie in Berlin, With a 3-Ton Camera
item.media:description: Susanna Kraus, left, the impresario and artist behind the Imago camera, unveiling a portrait of Christy Woody, right, in her Berlin studio. The photographs are taken straight onto reversal photo paper, not negative film.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Using complex and proprietary optics, the Imago camera creates life-size portraits directly on photo paper. A second Imago is in the works for Beijing.
item.dc:creator: GERRIT WIESMANN

item.title: China Welcomes Incoming Head of U.N., Where It Wants a Larger Role
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China arriving to meet António Guterres, the next secretary general of the United Nations, on Monday at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing.
item.description: The visit by António Guterres to Beijing was another chance for China to promote its growing role in global governance.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: A Malaysian Political Cartoonist on Facing His Fears, and Prison, for Art
item.media:description: The Malaysian political cartoonist who goes by the name Zunar is under investigation.
item.description: Zulkiflee Anwar Ulhaque, who goes by the name Zunar, is under investigation for producing cartoons that purportedly defamed Prime Minister Najib Razak.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Great Barrier Reef Hit by Worst Coral Die-Off on Record, Scientists Say
item.media:description: A field of staghorn coral this month killed by bleaching on Bourke Reef, a part of the 430-mile northern section of the Great Barrier Reef.
item.media:credit: Greg Torda/ARC Center of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies
item.description: About two-thirds of the shallow-water coral on the reef’s previously pristine, 430-mile northern stretch was dead, researchers reported.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Author’s Vision of a Future Beijing Looks to China’s Present
item.media:description: Hao Jingfang, whose science-fiction novelette “Folding Beijing” won a Hugo Award in August.
item.description: Hao Jingfang, the first Chinese woman to win a Hugo Award, reflects on the line between reality and fiction and giving voice to “invisible people.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Chapecoense Soccer Team’s Plane Crashes, Leaving Brazil Devastated
item.media:description: Rescue workers removing bodies of victims at the site of a plane crash on the outskirts of Medellín, Colombia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Few survivors have been found among the 77 on the chartered flight taking the team to a game in Medellín, Colombia. The crash came as fans across Brazil had been reveling in the team’s performance.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Dream of a Free Cuba
item.media:description: Watching President Obama deliver a speech during a visit to Havana in March.
item.description: The trade embargo has failed. What Cubans eager for the end of the Castro regime want is for the U.S. Congress to vote it down.
item.dc:creator: HENRY GODINEZ

item.title: Editorial Observer: In Paris, Worries That Trump Will Embolden Le Pen
item.media:description: A protester in Paris earlier this month.
item.description: The National Front candidate for French president views Donald Trump’s election as “good news for our country,” but others see much to protest.
item.dc:creator: MIRA KAMDAR

item.title: Editorial: Italy’s Turn to Vote
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy at a press conference on Monday.
item.description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi cannot undo his unwise push for a referendum, but he can mitigate its potential fallout.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
